title: 'Bubbly' mum suffers brain haemorrhage after suddenly collapsing before work
text:

A mum suffered a brain haemorrhage as she suddenly collapsed while getting ready for work one day.

Emma Bateman, 36, had no symptoms before she lost consciousness from a sudden thunderclap headache.

But the carer for young vulnerable adults with autism and mental health issues suffered a subarachnoid haemorrhage, most often caused by a burst blood vessel in the brain.

Her life has completely changed and she now uses a wheelchair and mobility scooter.

Emma's friends and family are hoping to raise £2000 to help fund her recovery.

When the Bateman family from Humberstone woke up on Saturday, June 15, they had no idea they were about to enter the most challenging period of their lives.

“It looked like she was having a heart attack,” husband Alan, 47, told Leicestershire Live.

“I called the hospital straight away," Alan said.

"They blue lighted her all the way to Queens Medical Centre in Nottingham.”

The mother of three had suffered a subarachnoid haemorrhage.

She was then told that there was another aneurysm located behind her right eye that will need to be monitored.

After 10 days in hospital she was ready to be cared for at home.

But her life is a lot different now. She uses a wheelchair and mobility scooter, and is missing her working life.

Alan, who works as a roofer, said: “She’s at the stage where she can take care of herself in short bursts.

“But she’s depressed because she likes her work and can’t do that anymore.

“She isn’t the same person anymore.

“But when you’ve been through something like that you take it day by day.

“All our lives have changed dramatically. The kids are helping a lot more and I’m trying to stick to working just six days a week."

With four children between them aged 25, 18, 16, and their nine-year-old who has autism, helping around the house, and with Alan often working seven days a week, the family has struggled through their most difficult time.

“I think we’ve got through the worst of it but we’re trying to catch up with bills now,” he added.

The money raised will go towards the bills the family has fallen behind on as well as travel costs getting Emma to and from Queens Medical Centre.

Friend Laura Smart, 35, said: “She struggles getting around and she gets confused.

“Emma was really bubbly and outgoing. Always up for a laugh, always out with friends and family.

“She was a carer for young vulnerable adults, and used to care for her husband's uncle too.

“But now she can’t do any of that.

“We hope to raise £2000 but whatever we can raise will be great.”

Donations to Emma’s GoFundMe page can be made here .
description: Emma Bateman's life has changed as she now uses a wheelchair and mobility scooter, and is missing work
